metadata.titleEn: High resolution atmosphere-hydrologic simulation dataset over the Tibetan Plateau (2000-2010)
metadata.description: The high-resolution atmosphere-hydrologic simulation dataset over Tibetan Plateau is prepared by WRFv4.1.1 model with grids of 191 * 355 and spatial resolution of 9 km, and a spatial range covering the entire plateau. The main physics schemes are configured with Thompson microphysics scheme, the rapid radiative transfer model (RRTM), and the Dudhia scheme for longwave and shortwave radiative flux calculations, respectively, the Mellor-Yamada-Janjic (MYJ) TKE scheme for the planetary boundary layer and the Unified Noah Land Surface Model. The time resolution is 3h and the time span is 2000-2010. Variables include: precipitation (Rain), temperature (T2) and water vapor (Q2) at 2m height on the ground, surface skin temperature (TSK), ground pressure (PSFC), zonal component (U10) and meridional component (V10) at 10m heigh on the ground, downward long-wave flux (GLW) and downward short-wave flux (SWDOWN) at surface, ground heat flux (GRDFLX), sensible heat flux (HFX), latent heat flux (LH), surface runoff (SFROFF) and underground runoff (UDROFF). The data can effectively support the study of regional climate characteristics, climate change and its impact over the Tibet Plateau, which will provide scientific basis for the sustainable development of the TP under the background of climate change.
metadata.instructions: Data storage and naming method: the data is in NetCDF format and is stored year by year according to variables, such as T2_ wrfout_ d01_ 2000.nc is the T2 data of 2000. The storage method is [month | 12] x [day | 31] x [hour | 8] x [south| North | 191] x [west| 355], where month is the 12 months of the year, day is the number of days of each month (less than 31 days set as the default), and hour corresponds to 00/03/06/09/12/15/18/21 of each day, South_ North and West_ East gives longitude and latitude. The related longitude and latitude information, terrain and land use data are stored in file of Static_lat_lon_wrfout_d01.nc.

literatureList.titleEn: Convection-permitting modeling over the Tibetan Plateau improves the simulation of Meiyu Rainfall during the 2011 Yangtze Plain flood

Convection-permitting modeling over the Tibetan Plateau improves the simulation of Meiyu Rainfall during the 2011 Yangtze Plain flood. Atmospheric Research, 265, 105907, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.atmosres.2021.105907.

background: The Tibetan Plateau (TP) plays a complicated impact on summer extreme precipitation in downstream areas like Yangtze Plain, and the convection-permitting modeling (CPM) over the TP has obvious added value for regional climate simulation.
research objective: This study investigates whether the CPM over the TP can improve the simulation of a typical extreme Meiyu rainfall in Yangtze Plain and the possible mechanism.
challenges: The complexity and heterogeneity of the underlying surface and terrain over the largest and highest plateau in the world limit the availability of observational data and development numerical model, which leads to considerable uncertainties in simulations of weather and climate over the TP.
methods: The Advanced Research Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) used in this study is version 4.1. The initial and boundary conditions for the large-scale atmospheric fields, as well as the initial soil parameters (soil water, moisture, and temperature), are obtained from the global atmospheric reanalysis data, ECMWF interim reanalysis (ERA-Interim). The sea surface temperature is updated during the simulation period by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Optimum Interpolation Sea Surface Temperature Analysis. Three experiments are conducted to investigate the influence of the CPM over the TP on the simulation of Meiyu rainfall and its possible mechanism. All experiments keep the same physical configurations in the WRF model and are started at 0000 UTC on May 15, 2011 and continue until 0000 UTC on July 1, 2011. Only the results from June 1 to June 30 are analyzed.
dataset: We apply the CN05.1 gridded daily precipitation dataset covered the period of 1961 – 2015 to investigate the precipitation anomaly in June 2011. The first two rainfall observation is from the real-time analysis system with 0.25° grids (OBS_0.25) and 0.1° grids (OBS_0.1) in China from the National Meteorological Information Center. The third data is the forcing dataset with 0.1° grids developed by the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau Research Institute of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (ITPCAS).
findings: Results reveal that the CPM over the TP better reproduces the regional climate over the TP in terms of the precipitation and temperature. The more realistic representation of the regional climate over the TP can further improve the simulation of the spatial distribution of rainfall, the maximum center of rainfall and heavy rainfall processes of Meiyu rainfall in June 2011 but with a wet bias, which could be attributed to too much convective precipitation caused by the cumulus parameterizations. This work demonstrates the potential for the more realistic representation of atmosphere and land surface information over TP to improve the simulations and prediction of extreme Meiyu rainfall.

Verification.Question: Does the use of the WRF 4.1.1 model include specific parameterization schemes for accurate simulation over the Tibetan Plateau?
Is the CN05.1 gridded daily precipitation dataset utilized for investigating precipitation anomalies over the Tibetan Plateau?
Do the challenges in simulating weather and climate over the Tibetan Plateau arise from the complexity and heterogeneity of its underlying surface and terrain?

Disjunctive.Question: Which data collection method is more suitable for simulating regional climate over the Tibetan Plateau: using ECMWF interim reanalysis data for large-scale atmospheric fields or using NOAA Optimum Interpolation Sea Surface Temperature Analysis?
Disjunctive.Answer: ECMWF interim reanalysis data for large-scale atmospheric fields

Disjunctive.Question: What is a more significant challenge in collecting observational data over the Tibetan Plateau: the complexity of the underlying surface and terrain or the development of numerical models?
Disjunctive.Answer: the complexity of the underlying surface and terrain

Concept Completion.Question: What are the main challenges faced in collecting observational data over the Tibetan Plateau?
Concept Completion.Answer: complexity and heterogeneity of the underlying surface and terrain

Concept Completion.Question: Where can one obtain the initial and boundary conditions for large-scale atmospheric fields used in simulation over the Tibetan Plateau?
What dataset is used to investigate precipitation anomalies in June 2011 over the Tibetan Plateau, and where is it applied?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to obtain high-resolution atmospheric and hydrological simulation data in the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: A data collection method for high-resolution atmospheric and hydrological simulation data in the Tibetan Plateau involves using the WRF4.1.1 model with key parameterization schemes such as the Thompson microphysics scheme, RRTM longwave radiation scheme, Dudhia shortwave radiation scheme, MYJ boundary layer scheme, and Noah land surface process scheme, collecting data over a grid of 191x355 with a spatial resolution of 9km and temporal resolution of 3 hours, spanning from 2000 to 2010.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of challenges faced in simulating weather and climate over the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: An example of challenges in simulating weather and climate over the Tibetan Plateau includes the complexity and heterogeneity of the underlying surface and terrain, which limit the availability of observational data and the development of numerical models, leading to considerable uncertainties in the simulations.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of a dataset used to investigate precipitation anomalies in the Tibetan Plateau region?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset used to investigate precipitation anomalies in the Tibetan Plateau region is the CN05.1 gridded daily precipitation dataset covering the period of 1961 – 2015, which is used alongside real-time analysis systems with 0.25° and 0.1° grids in China from the National Meteorological Information Center, and a forcing dataset with 0.1° grids developed by the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau Research Institute of the Chinese Academy of Sciences.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the main characteristics of the atmospheric and hydrological simulation data used for studying regional climate features over the Tibetan Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: high-resolution, spatial resolution of 9 km, temporal resolution of 3 hours, period from 2000 to 2010, precipitation, temperature at 2m height, humidity at 2m height, surface temperature, surface pressure, wind components at 10m height, longwave and shortwave fluxes, ground heat flux, sensible heat flux, latent heat flux, surface runoff, underground runoff

Feature Specification.Question: What are the challenges associated with numerical modeling and data collection in the Tibetan Plateau region?
Feature Specification.Answer: complexity, heterogeneity of the underlying surface and terrain, limited availability of observational data, considerable uncertainties in simulations

Quantification.Question: What is the spatial resolution of a high-resolution atmospheric-hydrological simulation dataset over the Tibetan Plateau?
How many grid points are used in the atmospheric-hydrological simulation dataset for the Tibetan Plateau?
Over what time span is the high-resolution atmospheric-hydrological simulation dataset for the Tibetan Plateau available?

Definition.Question: What is the 'WRF4.1.1 model' used for in atmospheric-hydrological simulations?
Definition.Answer: The WRF4.1.1 model is used for conducting high-resolution atmospheric-hydrological simulations over regions like the Tibetan Plateau, applying specific parameterization schemes for microphysics, radiation, boundary layer processes, and land surface processes to produce a detailed dataset.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods used in atmospheric-hydrological models on the Tibetan Plateau compare to those used for precipitation anomaly studies in China?
Comparison.Answer: The atmospheric-hydrological models on the Tibetan Plateau use high-resolution simulations with WRF 4.1.1, incorporating reanalysis data for atmospheric fields and NOAA sea surface temperatures, while precipitation anomaly studies in China utilize CN05.1 gridded datasets and real-time analysis systems with different grid resolutions.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced when collecting observational data over the Tibetan Plateau compared to other regions like the Yangtze Plain?
Comparison.Answer: The Tibetan Plateau presents challenges due to its complex terrain and limited observational data, leading to uncertainties in climate simulations, whereas regions like the Yangtze Plain may benefit from more uniform topography and potentially greater availability of observational data.

Interpretation.Question: How might the spatial resolution of a dataset collected using numerical models like WRF influence the accuracy and reliability of climate simulations over complex terrains such as the Tibetan Plateau?
Interpretation.Answer: The spatial resolution of a dataset, like the 9km resolution used in the WRF model, can significantly affect the accuracy of climate simulations over the Tibetan Plateau due to its complex and heterogeneous terrain. Higher resolution can capture more detailed variations in topography and land surface processes, leading to better representation of regional climate patterns and extreme weather events.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways could the integration of additional observational data sources enhance the reliability of datasets used for modeling climate phenomena on the Tibetan Plateau?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of additional observational data sources, such as more comprehensive rainfall observations and soil moisture data, could enhance the reliability of datasets by providing more accurate initial and boundary conditions for models. This could reduce uncertainties in simulations, improving the representation of climate phenomena like precipitation and temperature over the Tibetan Plateau.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the complexity and heterogeneity of the underlying surface and terrain to limit the availability of observational data and development of numerical models over the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The Tibetan Plateau, being the largest and highest plateau in the world, presents a highly complex and heterogeneous surface and terrain. This complexity affects the availability of observational data and the development of numerical models, leading to considerable uncertainties in simulations of weather and climate over the region due to challenges in accurately representing the diverse conditions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it necessary to update the sea surface temperature during the simulation period when using the Advanced Research Weather Research and Forecasting model?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Updating the sea surface temperature during the simulation period is crucial because it ensures the model accurately reflects the evolving oceanic conditions, which can significantly influence atmospheric processes. In the context of the Tibetan Plateau, accurate sea surface temperature data is necessary to improve the representation of atmospheric and land surface interactions, thereby enhancing the simulation of regional climate and extreme weather events.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the wet bias observed in the simulation of Meiyu rainfall over the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The wet bias in the simulation of Meiyu rainfall over the Tibetan Plateau is attributed to excessive convective precipitation caused by the cumulus parameterizations used in the model. This suggests that while the model may improve the spatial distribution and intensity of rainfall, adjustments in the parameterizations are needed to reduce the wet bias and improve simulation accuracy.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using the Thompson microphysics scheme in atmospheric-hydrological simulations over the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing the Thompson microphysics scheme can result in a more accurate representation of precipitation processes, which is crucial for simulating extreme weather events like the Meiyu rainfall. This can lead to improved predictions and understanding of regional climatic phenomena, though it may also introduce biases such as overestimation of convective precipitation.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to improve the simulation of extreme Meiyu rainfall events in regions downstream of the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to enhance the understanding and prediction of regional climate patterns, particularly by addressing the added value of convection-permitting modeling over the Tibetan Plateau, which can potentially improve the representation of rainfall distribution, intensity, and processes in downstream areas like the Yangtze Plain.

Goal Orientation.Question: What challenges are addressed by developing datasets with a spatial resolution of 9 km and a temporal resolution of 3 hours for the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The challenges addressed include the complexity and heterogeneity of the terrain and surface in the Tibetan Plateau, which limits observational data availability and adds uncertainties in numerical weather and climate simulations. High-resolution datasets aim to mitigate these issues by providing more accurate atmospheric and land surface information.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instrumentation and procedural steps are involved in setting up a high-resolution atmospheric-hydrological simulation using the WRF model for data collection over the Tibetan Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The simulation setup involves using the WRF version 4.1.1 model with specific parameterization schemes including the Thompson microphysics scheme, RRTM longwave radiation scheme, Dudhia shortwave radiation scheme, MYJ boundary layer scheme, and Noah land surface model. The model uses initial and boundary conditions from global atmospheric reanalysis data, specifically the ECMWF interim reanalysis (ERA-Interim), and updates sea surface temperature during the simulation with data from NOAA's Optimum Interpolation Sea Surface Temperature Analysis.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are the challenges of complex terrain and surface heterogeneity over the Tibetan Plateau addressed in the procedural framework of climate modeling to minimize uncertainties?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedural framework addresses these challenges by employing convection-permitting modeling (CPM) which adds value to regional climate simulation. The framework involves using high-resolution models and datasets, such as the CN05.1 gridded daily precipitation dataset, to improve the spatial representation of climate features and mitigate uncertainties due to complex terrain and surface heterogeneity.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the simulation of high-resolution atmospheric and hydrological data over the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The use of the WRF4.1.1 model with specific parameterization schemes such as the Thompson microphysics scheme, RRTM longwave radiation scheme, Dudhia shortwave radiation scheme, MYJ boundary layer scheme, and Noah land surface scheme enables the simulation of high-resolution atmospheric and hydrological data over the Tibetan Plateau.

Enablement.Question: How do specific data collection methods address the challenges posed by the complex and heterogeneous terrain of the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The complexity and heterogeneity of the terrain limit observational data availability, which is mitigated by using global atmospheric reanalysis data like ECMWF interim reanalysis (ERA-Interim) and real-time analysis systems with varying grid resolutions to provide comprehensive initial and boundary conditions for modeling efforts.

Expectation.Question: Why might the complexity and heterogeneity of the Tibetan Plateau's terrain pose challenges for data collection and simulation accuracy in atmospheric-hydrological models?
Expectation.Answer: The complexity and heterogeneity of the underlying surface and terrain over the Tibetan Plateau limit the availability of observational data and development numerical models, which leads to considerable uncertainties in simulations of weather and climate over the region.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be a wet bias in the simulation of regional climate models over the Tibetan Plateau, and how could this impact the representation of extreme rainfall events?
Expectation.Answer: The wet bias in the simulation could be attributed to too much convective precipitation caused by the cumulus parameterizations. This may impact the representation of extreme rainfall events by affecting the simulation of the spatial distribution and processes of heavy rainfall.

Judgmental.Question: How effective do you perceive the use of convection-permitting modeling (CPM) over the Tibetan Plateau in improving regional climate simulations?
Judgmental.Answer: The CPM over the Tibetan Plateau is perceived as effective in improving regional climate simulations, particularly in reproducing regional climate features like precipitation and temperature. It enhances the simulation of the spatial distribution and intensity of rainfall events, despite some biases due to convective precipitation parameterizations.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the challenges associated with collecting observational data over the Tibetan Plateau, and how might these challenges impact the accuracy of atmospheric modeling?
Judgmental.Answer: The challenges associated with collecting observational data over the Tibetan Plateau include its complex and heterogeneous terrain, which limits data availability and complicates numerical modeling. These challenges contribute to uncertainties in weather and climate simulations over the region, impacting the accuracy of atmospheric modeling.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data is collected or simulated over complex terrains like the Tibetan Plateau, considering the varied surface and limited observational data.
Assertion.Answer: The Advanced Research Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) model version 4.1 is used, incorporating global atmospheric reanalysis data from ECMWF interim reanalysis (ERA-Interim) for initial and boundary conditions and NOAA Optimum Interpolation Sea Surface Temperature Analysis for sea surface temperature updates. These methods help simulate weather and climate over the Tibetan Plateau despite its complexity and heterogeneity.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about the challenges involved in ensuring accuracy in datasets for regional climate simulations over the Tibetan Plateau.
Assertion.Answer: The complexity and heterogeneity of the underlying surface and terrain over the Tibetan Plateau, the largest and highest plateau in the world, limit the availability of observational data and the development of numerical models. This leads to considerable uncertainties in simulations of weather and climate over the region.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how datasets can effectively support regional climate characteristic and climate change research over the Tibetan Plateau.
Assertion.Answer: Datasets like the high-resolution atmospheric-hydrological simulation dataset for the Tibetan Plateau, with a spatial resolution of 9 km and a temporal resolution of 3 hours, provide detailed variables such as precipitation, temperature, humidity, and various fluxes. These datasets help researchers understand and analyze regional climate characteristics and climate changes in the Tibetan Plateau area.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the various data collection methods utilized for obtaining high-resolution atmospheric and hydrological simulation data related to the Tibetan Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods for high-resolution atmospheric and hydrological simulation data over the Tibetan Plateau involve utilizing the WRF4.1.1 model with specific parameterization schemes such as the Thompson microphysics scheme, RRTM longwave radiation scheme, Dudhia shortwave radiation scheme, MYJ boundary layer scheme, and the Noah land surface process scheme. The initial and boundary conditions are derived from global atmospheric reanalysis data, and sea surface temperatures are updated using NOAA Optimum Interpolation Sea Surface Temperature Analysis.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in the collection and simulation of climate data over the Tibetan Plateau and suggest strategies to overcome them.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in collecting and simulating climate data over the Tibetan Plateau include the complexity and heterogeneity of the underlying surface and terrain, which limit observational data availability and numerical model development. This leads to uncertainties in weather and climate simulations. To overcome these challenges, researchers can employ convection-permitting modeling (CPM) techniques and use gridded datasets such as CN05.1 and those developed by the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau Research Institute for more accurate simulations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please suggest potential datasets that can be used to investigate precipitation anomalies and extreme weather events over the Tibetan Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets for investigating precipitation anomalies and extreme weather events over the Tibetan Plateau include the CN05.1 gridded daily precipitation dataset, real-time analysis systems with 0.25° and 0.1° grids from the National Meteorological Information Center, and the forcing dataset with 0.1° grids developed by the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau Research Institute of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (ITPCAS). These datasets provide comprehensive coverage and are suitable for analyzing regional climate characteristics and events.
